Models#

XGBoost#

XGBoost is a decision-tree-based ensemble Machine Learning algorithm that uses a gradient boosting framework.

class models.XGBoost.xgboost(df, target, test_size)[source]#

Bases: object

class to create the xgboost model

pandas dataframe with the time series as columns

Type:

pandas dataframe

target#

name of target column to forecast

Type:

str

test_size#

the percentage size of the test set from 0 to 1

Type:

float

Import and usage:

from src.models.xgboost import xgboost

xgboost_model = xgboost(df, target, test_size)

pred, test, train = xgboost_model.fit()

CNN#

Convolutional Neural Network, CNN is a type of neural network that can be used for time series forecasting by using convolutional layers.

class models.cnn.cnn(df, target, test_size, plot_learning_curves_bool=False)[source]#

Bases: object

This class is used to forecast time series data using Convolutional Neural Network.

Attributes :

df (pandas dataframe) : pandas dataframe with the time series as columns

target (str) : name of target column to forecast

test_size (float) : the percentage size of the test set from 0 to 1

plot_learning_curves_bool (bool) : boolean to plot learning curves or not, default is False

Import and usage:

from src.models.cnn import cnn

cnn_model = cnn(df, target, test_size, plot_learning_curves_bool)

pred, test, train = cnn_model.fit()

forecast = cnn_model.forecast(new_data)

create_model(custom_model)[source]#

Create the CNN model.

By default, the model has 2 convolutional layers, 1 max pooling layer, 1 flatten layer, 2 dense layers and 1 output layer.

The model is compiled with the adam optimizer and the mean squared error loss function.

However, you can define your own architecture by providing your own Sequential model architecture from keras.

fit()[source]#

This function is used to train, test and forecast time series data using cnn neural networks.

Returns :

predictions (pandas series) : pandas series of the predictions

test (pandas series) : pandas series of the test values

train (pandas series) : pandas series of the train values

forecast(new_data)[source]#

This function is used to forecast time series data using CNN neural networks on new_data.

Parameters :

new_data (numpy array) : numpy array of the new data to forecast

Returns :

predictions (numpy array) : numpy array of the predictions

plot_learning_curves(history)[source]#
plot_predictions(predictions)[source]#
train_test_sets()[source]#

GRU#

Gated Recurrent Unit, is a simplified version of LSTM that is also used for time series forecasting.

class models.gru.gru(df, target, test_size, plot_learning_curves_bool=False, epochs=200, batch_size=30)[source]#

Bases: object

This class is used to forecast time series data using Gated Recurrent Unit neural network.

Attributes:

df (pandas dataframe): pandas dataframe with the time series as columns

target (str): name of target column to forecast

test_size (float): the percentage size of the test set from 0 to 1

plot_learning_curves_bool (bool): boolean to plot learning curves or not, default is False

Import and usage :

from src.models.gru import gru

gru_model = gru(df, target, test_size, plot_learning_curves_bool)

pred, test, train = gru_model.fit()

forecast = gru_model.forecast(new_data)

create_model(custom_model)[source]#

Create the GRU model. By default, the model is a sequential model with 3 GRU layers and 3 dense layers. The loss function is mean squared error and the optimizer is adam. However, you can define your own architecture by providing your own Sequential model architecture from keras.

fit()[source]#

This function is used to train, test and forecast time series data using gru neural networks.

forecast(new_data)[source]#

This function is used to forecast time series data using GRU neural networks on new_data.

Parameters:

new_data (numpy array): The new data to forecast on. The shape of the array should be (n_samples, n_timesteps, n_features).

Returns:

predictions (numpy array): The predictions of the model on the new data. The shape of the array is (n_samples, 1).

plot_learning_curves(history)[source]#
plot_predictions(predictions)[source]#
train_test_sets()[source]#

LSTM#

Long Short Term Memory, LSTM is a type of recurrent neural network (RNN) that can learn long-term dependencies between time steps of sequence data.

class models.lstm.lstm(df, target, test_size, plot_learning_curves_bool=False, epochs=200, batch_size=30)[source]#

Bases: object

This class is used to forecast time series data using Long Short Term Memory.

df#

pandas dataframe with the time series as columns

Type:

pandas dataframe

target#

name of target column to forecast

Type:

str

test_size#

the percentage size of the test set from 0 to 1

Type:

float

plot_learning_curves_bool#

boolean to plot learning curves or not, default is False

Type:

bool

Import and usage:

from src.models.lstm import lstm

lstm_model = lstm(df, target, test_size, plot_learning_curves_bool)

predictions, test, train = lstm_model.fit()

forecast = lstm_model.forecast(new_data)

create_model(custom_model)[source]#

This method is used to create the LSTM model. By default, the model has 3 LSTM layers and 2 Dense layers. However, you can define your own architecture by calling this method and providing your own Sequential model architecture from keras.

fit()[source]#

This method is used to train, test and forecast time series data using LSTM neural networks.

forecast(new_data)[source]#

This method is used to forecast new time series data using the trained LSTM model

Parameters:

new_data: (Numpy array) The new input data to be forecasted.

Returns:

predictions: (Numpy array) The forecasted values.

plot_learning_curves(history)[source]#

This function is used to plot the learning curves of the neural network.

plot_predictions(predictions)[source]#

This function is used to plot the predictions vs the actual train and test values.

train_test_sets()[source]#

This function is used to split the data into train and test sets.

SARIMA#

Seasonal Auto Regressive Integrated Mooving Average, SRIMA is an extension of ARIMA that supports the direct modeling of the seasonal component of the series.

class models.sarima.sarima(time_series, target, test_size_prct, p, d, q, P, D, Q, m)[source]#

Bases: object

This class is implementing the forecasting of the time series using the SARIMA model

Parameters:

time_series (pandas series): time series to forecast

target (str): name of target column to forecast

test_size_prct (float): the percentage size of the test set from 0 to 1

p (int): order of the AR part of the model

d (int): order of the I part of the model

q (int): order of the MA part of the model

P (int): order of the seasonal AR part of the model

D (int): order of the seasonal I part of the model

Q (int): order of the seasonal MA part of the model

m (int): number of time steps for a seasonal period

Import and usage:

from src.models.sarima import sarima

sarima_model = sarima(time_series, target, test_size_prct, p, d, q, P, D, Q, m)

forecast, test, model_fit = sarima_model.fit()

evaluate(predictions)[source]#

Evaluate the SARIMA model using the mean absolute error.

fit()[source]#

Fit the SARIMA model to the time series.

help()[source]#
plot_results(predictions, model_fit)[source]#

Plot the results of the SARIMA model.

run()[source]#

Run the SARIMA model.

VAR#

Vector Auto Regression, VAR is a multivariate forecasting algorithm that is used when two or more time series influence each other.

class models.var.var(df, target, test_size, max_lag)[source]#

Bases: object

This class is used to forecast and model time series data using VAR models.

Parameters:

  • df (pandas dataframe) – pandas dataframe with the time series as columns

  • target (str) – name of target column to forecast

  • test_size (float) – the percentage size of the test set from 0 to 1

  • max_lag (int) – the maximum number of lags to use in the VAR model

Returns:

a dataframe with the original data and the modelled data in a new column with the name of the target + “_simulated”

Return type:

dataframe

remark: the VAR model is not a forecasting model, it is a modelling tool. The VAR model is used to model the time series and then the model is used to forecast the time series.

The VAR model is a multivariate model, it uses all the columns of the dataframe to model the target column.

In fact with this implementation the var modelling is applied on all columns of the dataframe from the others.

Import and usage:

from src.models.var import var

var_model = var(df, target, test_size, max_lag)

forecast, test, train = var_model.fit()

extract_var_equations(data, results_params)[source]#

Extract the equations

extract_var_results(results)[source]#

VAR results analysis and selection (statistical test)

fit()[source]#

var main function

forecast(new_data)[source]#

forecast function: use the VAR model equation to forecast the time series

Args: new_data (pandas dataframe): dataframe with the same columns as the training data /!don’t forget to add the max_lag number of rows before the first row of the new data that you want to forecast since we use the lagged values to forecast.

get_lag_series(col, results_params)[source]#

This function returns an array from the VAR results with 3 elements: name: name of the serie lag: delay col: the serie that we model

plot_predictions(predictions)[source]#
run_var(data, max_lag)[source]#

Initialise and run VAR
